newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila's PHIBOR rates continue downward trend.
newsitem.headline: Manila's PHIBOR rates continue downward trend.

text.p: News that bank reserve requirements will be cut by two percentage points next year sent Philippine interbank offered rates (PHIBOR) lower, traders said on Friday. Only the three-month rate was unchanged.

"By January, there'll be more liquidity," said a trader, prodding banks to revise their swap rates. The Central Bank said the cut in reserve requirements is expected to release 13.4 billion pesos in funds to banks.
The three-month rate, however, was steady because interest rates may have stabilised by March next year following the first rate cut, the same dealer said.

On Thursday, the Central Bank announced that reserve requirements for banks would be cut to 13 percent from 15, to be implemented in two phases over 1997, the first on January 3 and the second on July 4.
Central Bank research director Diwa Gunigundo told Reuters the 13.4 billion pesos that will be freed will result in an additional 54.8 billion pesos ($2.087 billion) to total domestic liquidity.
Average rates quoted by 20 banks were:
